description: Animal ID #723825 How this pet arrived: Dream was brought in by his previous owner on March 19, 2021. Why this pet is the one for you: This is Dream! Dream is a wonderful guinea pig, looking for a home to call his own. Dream is still getting used to being picked up and handled, but with lots of patience and socialization, he will be a wonderful piggy! Dream will need a large enclosure and plenty of time outside of the cage, which will be great for bonding and growing closer with him! Dream loves to eat Timothy hay (and should be provided an unlimited amount), pellets, and fresh greens every day. He will also need his Vitamin C supplemented, as guinea pigs do not produce their own - bell peppers are a good source! We recommend doing plenty of research before making him part of your family! Interested in a cute guinea pig to call your own? Make an appointment online to learn more! Primary Color: White Secondary Color: Black Weight: 2.32lbs Age: 1yrs 0mths 0wks

Mr. Bean will need a large enclosure (at least 8 sq. ft.) to run around and should get daily "floor time," outside of his cage. Mr. Bean loves to eat Timothy hay (and should be provided an unlimited amount), pellets, and fresh greens every day. #717640Age: Mature AdultWeight: Unknown How this pet arrived:This pet was brought in by their Previous Owner on March 19th, 2021. At SDHS:This pet has been receiving excellent care! Why this pet is the one for you: Meet Rhino! He is looking for a rat-savvy human who will spend lots of time with him. Rats are social creatures, so Rhino will need to go with his best buddies Granger (717638) and Dino (717639) Rats need to have a nice spacious enclosure (4 or 5 cubic feet) filled with toys, hammocks, and hiding holes. Get creative! There is a wonderful DIY community for rat enrichment. At meal times, you can provide them with their rat pellets, safe fruits, and veggies! Monitor their intake of sweet/fatty foods so they can stay fit, healthy and happy. They'd love to get out of the enclosure to get a good stretch! Just be sure to put up all the cords and other chewable items, as well as blocking off any potential hiding spots that you can't reach. You can set them up with different toys and mazes and watch them break a mental sweat! Rats are extremely intelligent and love to work out puzzles in exchange for tasty snacks. Doesn't that sound like the perfect way to spend the day? Click on "Adopt Me" to get started! Primary Color: White

#723885Age: 3 Years Weight: 1lb 12 oz How this pet arrived: This pet was brought in by their previous owner on March 19, 2021. At SDHS:This pet has been receiving excellent care and is now ready for their new home! Why this pet is the one for you:Meet Bubbles! He is a wonderful guinea pig looking for a home to call his own. Bubbles enjoys snacks, his comfy house, and play time with his favorite humans! Guinea pigs are incredibly social animals who need to be kept in pairs to thrive. Bubbles came in alone, so if you have a single, male Guinea Pig at home, they might make the perfect pair! Bubbles has lived with another Guinea Pig in the past and done well. If Bubbles is in our care when another single male comes in, we might try to see if we can make him a friend and send them home together! Guinea pigs need a lot of ground space to run around and stay healthy. Two guinea pigs will need a minimum of 10 sq feet of space (more is better!) to call home. An easy and inexpensive way to give your pigs a DIY piggy palace is called a C&C fleece lined cage (google it!). Guinea pigs need lots of daily timothy hay to munch on, extra space to run around in, and toys to keep them active and enriched! Healthy greens and veggies are also an essential part of their diet, as well as a daily dose of vitamin C in the form of a supplement or a slice of orange! Bubbles has done well with children in his previous home, is friendly, and tolerates handling. He really is quite the catch! If you'd like to learn more, book an appointment today! Primary Color: Tri Color Weight: 1.8lbs Age: 3yrs 9mths 2wks

Maiev is a crested agouti roan mix female born to one of our rescues on February 4, 2021. She's still a baby, so will need taming, but she's gentle and bright and will learn easily. She is learning "cookie time", and will take a syringe for vitamin C if you pick her up. She has been checked by a vet and is healthy.,,Maiev is used to living in a herd, and could match up with one of our pairs, other singles, or your own female guinea pig who needs a friend. A bonding session would be performed with your existing piggie to ensure compatibility.,,**We highly recommend that baby guinea pigs have vitamin C supplement daily until 4- 5 months old.,**The minimum space required for a pair of guinea pigs is 8 square feet of FLAT floor space, with at least 2 foot in width. Second stories would be considered additional space and not counted as part of the required minimum. We can advise on cage size for 3 or more.,**Bunny hutches are not acceptable housing for guinea pigs.,**Adoption fees are $35, single; $50, pair; $70, trio.,,Video and more pictures coming soon!

Hi! My name is Dax! I am a super cool bunny with the best personality! I love to be petted and held. I have participated in the Rescue Readers program here at the shelter and I am quite popular. The kiddos love me, and I love them! I would make a great companion for any person. Another awesome thing about me: I love to play fetch! If you throw me a ball, I will bat at it and throw it around. I am also a big boy. I love to eat, and it shows. You could think of me as a small dog. My previous home surrendered me to the shelter because they got a new dog who didn't know how to act around me. The staff isn't sure how I am with other animals yet. Rabbits can live over ten years, require space and commitment, and can be costly. They are social animals who want your attention and who each have their own personalities. Rabbits are fragile and have delicate spines, so their owner must be educated on proper rabbit handling. Because of this, rabbits do best with adults and older children. Rabbits need a large cage with a hide shelter, water bottle and food bowl, toys like balls and chew sticks, and a hay rack. They can be litter box trained, which means they also need a litter box. A healthy rabbit's diet consists of 80% hay with timothy, grass, and oat hays for older rabbits and alfalfa hay for young rabbits. Rabbits also need a large variety of vegetables and greens, a limited amount of rabbit food pellets, and the very occasional sugary treat like carrots or berries. Rabbits get bored just like the rest of us, and enjoy ripping up newspaper and playing with carboard boxes and toilet paper rolls. Rabbits can be messy and enjoy rearranging their cages exactly how they like it! They need room to roam and exercise outside of their cage each day, but it is very important to rabbit-proof your home areas before letting the rabbit out. They love to chew on wires and destroy paperwork, and should always be supervised. Adoption Fee: $30.00 Our bunnies are for indoors only. Adoption includes their neuter and microchip.

Sonic was born to one of our rescues on February 4, 2021, along with 3 siblings.  He's a white crested roan mix.  He's playful and talkative.,,Knuckles was originally paired with another piggie, but they broke up when he hit puberty, so we let him choose a new pal.  Sonic was a natural match!  Knuckles was born around October 13, 2020, and has been with us since December, 2020.,,These bright boys play and cuddle together.  They are active, sweet, gentle, and still shy.  As Sonic gets older and the both bond with their new family, they'll become more tame.  They're learning "cookie time" and will take a syringe for vitamin C if picked up.,,With a little gentle taming work, these playful piggie boys will be good companions for children who know how to handle small pets (under supervision, please).,,**Male guinea pigs should only be kept in pairs.,**We highly recommend that baby guinea pigs have vitamin C supplement daily until 4- 5 months old.,**The minimum space required for a pair of guinea pigs is 8 square feet of FLAT floor space, with at least 2 foot in width. Second stories would be considered additional space and not counted as part of the required minimum.,**Bunny hutches are not acceptable housing for guinea pigs.,,Video and more photos coming soon!

Hanzo is a 5 month old tri-colour guinea pig.  His buddy Genji is a tri-colour roan mix piggie born to one of our rescues on January 31, 2021.,,Hanzo was originally paired with a different friend, but they broke up when his pal went through puberty.  After trying a few boys together, Hanzo and Genji chose each other.  They are playful, sweet boys.  Hanzo does zoomies and popcorns and gets Genji to follow him.  They often cuddle together, too.,,Both boys are learning "cookie time" and will take a syringe for vitamin C if you pick them up.  Being young, Genji still needs taming.  Hanzo is particularly bright and easy to work with.  They are cuddly and gentle.,,Hanzo & Genji are playful piggies who would be good companions for children who know how to handle small pets (under supervision, please).,,**Male guinea pigs should only be kept in pairs.,**We highly recommend that baby guinea pigs have vitamin C supplement daily until 4- 5 months old.,**The minimum space required for a pair of guinea pigs is 8 square feet of FLAT floor space, with at least 2 foot in width. Second stories would be considered additional space and not counted as part of the required minimum.,**Bunny hutches are not acceptable housing for guinea pigs.,,,Video and more pictures coming soon!,

We love odd couples, and Leppie and Snuffy are just that.,,These brothers.... from very different mothers.... are happy to hang out, snuggle, and explore. They spend most of their days napping together, chowing down on some veggies (pretty sure Snuffy eats most of them...) and exploring. Having lived the majority of their lives together, Snuffy and Leppie would love to find a home together, where they can continue to do so.,,Having lived with dogs previously, they could probably do so again, though they prefer dogs that pay them no attention. Sometimes they startle easy when the dogs move quickly.,,These boys do well with plenty of space, afterall, Snuffy is a big guy. Snuffy can get defensive of his territory if there's not enough room. We recommend a dog exercise pen at the very least, with plenty of run around out of cage time. Though they haven't lived with kids, would likely be fine with older children who are patient with what it takes to win a rabbit's trust.,,For more information about Leppie and Snuffy, call the shelter at 603-472-3647 x201. Staff are happy to talk to you further about these guys, rabbits and the care they require and set up an appointment for you to meet them!

This respectable lady is just looking for a quiet home where she can build her confidence.,,She's been exposed to dogs, and was nervous of them, but could potentially live with dogs and cats that showed no interest in her. Atilla is a shy guy but warms up if you take things slowly.  He weighs just over 3 pounds.  He has been neutered and is working on litter box training.,Rabbits are great pets, but they have very specific care needs that must be taken care of for them to live happy and healthy lives! Make sure you are committed to meeting these requirements if you are thinking of adopting from us!,,- They must have a large, clean cage with solid floors and either shredded paper bedding or fleece covering them (wood bedding can cause respiratory illness). They can also be house trained with some patience! Rabbits are very active and smart, so they require lots of space to explore and run around in! In addition to a large area, you will have to give them lots of rabbit-safe toys to play with to keep them occupied and content. Contact us to get a list of appropriate enrichment ideas and cage recommendations!,,- They must have a good quality pellet, with no dried fruit, nuts, seeds, colored bits or processed sugary treats. Ingredients like these pose a choking hazard and can also cause illness due to an imbalanced diet. We like to feed our rabbits Oxbow brand rabbit food because it is free from all of the above! Spending a bit more money for good food will save in vet bills later!,,- They require vet care. While they don't need vaccinations, they can become ill or have injuries. They need care just like a dog or cat! We can point you in the direction of an exotics vet if you don't have one already!,,- They are fragile animals, therefore children must be supervised while handling them. - We do not adopt out small animals to homes with unfixed animals of the opposite gender. If you feel you are an exception to this, please talk with staff about your situation!

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Meet Harper Lee! Born around January 2018, she is beautiful, loving, joyful Pyrenees mix.,,Harper's life started out a little rocky. She was found as a hungry puppy, wandering the streets. Soon after being found, she became seriously ill and was rushed to an emergency veterinarian who found that Harper had eaten a latex glove! The glove was removed during surgery, and Harper made a full recovery.,,Fast forward to the present, as Harper was living happy life in a memory care center during the COVID pandemic. The facility underwent construction due to damage from "snow-mageddon," residents were moved amongst facilities, and the chaos became too much for our sweet Harper. She needs a steady, predictable environment.,,Harper is a sensitive soul and her feelings are easily hurt with a reprimand. She is incredibly loving and cuddly. If you are okay with her fur and the space she takes up in a bed, she would love to sleep with you. If you'd rather not have her on the furniture, she will happily sleep on a fluffy dog bed nearby.,,She makes a silly grumble growly sound when she's excited and greeting people she likes. It can sound intimidating at first, but she is just saying, "Hi! Love me!",,Harper has been exposed to children of all ages. She loves older children who can run and play and scratch her belly. She can be over-protective of babies.,,Harper has lived in households with multiple cats and dogs. She occasionally chases the cats, but is for the most part respectful of their space. She is respectful and usually submissive to the dogs as well. She can sometimes be possessive of food. She would be fine as an only dog or with other doggie companions.,,She loves soft plush squeaky toys - the noisier the better! She also enjoys a good game of tug of war.,,Harper has a good foundation in training. She knows all the basic commands and enjoys "shaking hands." She walks well on a leash after the initial excitement wears off. She crates well and will often seek out her crate if she is feeling insecure.,,SPIN Pyrs are all in foster homes in the Dallas/Fort Worth area. Potential adopters are asked to make travel arrangements if they live elsewhere. All SPIN dogs are spayed or neutered, current on vaccinations and on heartworm prevention. Please go to our website www.SpinRescue.org and fill out an application for this great Great Pyrenees!

Roscoe is the sweetest boy you'll ever meet. He came to us after being surrendered to an emergency care facility with a severe injury to his left arm. Lola is a approximately 4 year old, 18 to 20 pound, Beagle/Terrier mix. She is nothing but PURE ADORABLE!!  Lola and her pups (pups all adopted)were rescued in a rural area in MS. Lola has pretty apricot/red color with white accents on her face and feet..  These starving babies were left at a abandoned house in MS.  We knocked on the neighbors door to see about them, they said neighbors moved off in middle of the night.  We loaded all of them!  Lola is a great girl.. Super sweet and super calm... SNUGGLE BUG-loves to snuggle with everything!! She loves a calm house, and will want to be on the couch with you watching tv or snuggled up in her dog bed with another dog. She is what we call a easy dog.. not demanding.. just so sweet and she is also good with cats.  We are looking for a retired couple that is home a lot and will spoil her. She deserves it!!! She is a "kind" soul and just wants love... We would LOVE if her new adopter had another dog to hang around with.  Lola was a great moma to her pups and she knew the second we were their to help rescue her and her babies, she was beyond grateful.. SHE IS PRECIOUS!!!!! We are looking for owner occupants, someone that is retired or home a good bit that does not mind a dog jumping on the couch or being around them all the time.. This is a special girl!!!! A true SOUTHERN JEWEL!!! We promised her that she would NEVER be abandoned again EVER! Lola has been completely vetted to include spayed, shots, bordetella, rabies, wormed, heartworm TREATED for heartworms with a SPLIT safe treatment and now she is ready to go to her forever home. Her adoption fee is $595.00 and this already includes the transport fee.  We are a 501c3 and her adoption fee is a tax deduction for you.  We thank you in advance for saving a life!  Every adoption allows us to rescue another innocent life that would perish in a pound. If you are interested in adopting Lola contact Shelly at :    lovedogs.rescue@gmail.com

Whenever a sweet and engaging scruffy coated dog finds themselves in an urgent situation, Farfelâ€™s is more than happy to help them find the home that they deserve. Sweet Nicole found herself stuck in a small high kill shelter in rural New Mexico. Now Nicole is headed to Colorado to find her forever home!,,Nicole is about 5 or 6 years old. She is a very sweet, friendly little girl. The vets believe her to be a Yorkie/Carin Terrier mix. Nicole weighs only 9 lbs - the perfect size to accompany her people anywhere!,,While Nicole is a very engaging girl, always expect an adjustment period when introducing a dog to a new home setting. With any rescue, moving from a shelter to a foster or to an adoptive home can be very confusing. When an adopting family is sensitive to the challenges of change and acclimation for these dog's, the transition is far easier. A home with a very loving and nurturing family that understands that blossoming takes time would be perfect home for Nicole. Socialization, pure love and belly rubs is a gift to a dog that is undergoing a life change. Given the time and space, these dogs shine.,,Farfel's Rescue has found over time (we've rescued more than 3,000 dogs over 15 years of rescue) that families that attend level 1 group training classes or address individual challenges at home with one of our approved positive reinforcement/force free trainers keep their dogs for life. Dogs that do not get proper training and socialization have a much higher risk of developing behavioral problems. There is a bonding that occurs through the training process that can't be duplicated. It also teaches behaviors that enable a dog to go out into the world with excellent manners that create a very respectful relationship between dogs and their humans. It is for all these reasons that Farfel's isn't willing to adopt to a family that doesn't choose to create this training relationship. Farfel's is happy to provide a list of approved positive reinforcement/ force-free trainers in your area.,,Nicole is up to date on her vaccines, but not yet spayed. Spay must be done within 1 month of adoption, no exceptions! Farfelâ€™s rescue will cover all costs of Nicoleâ€™s spay!,,Nicole is arriving on transport in Boulder on 3/24/2021. Applications are currently being accepted for our wonderful pup. If interested in this gorgeous, very cuddly/sweet and loving best friend, please fill out an application completely at http://farfels.com/farfels-rescue/adoption-form/ and submit.,,**PLEASE NOTE** If you're truly interested in adopting from us, please be sure to fill out our Farfel's Rescue adoption application found at the link above or at farfels.com. Adoption site applications such as Petfinder, Rescueme and Adoptapet don't provide enough information and therefore aren't useful. Our Farfel's application is the only initial tool that we have to determine a great match for this very deserving puppy. We're sorry, but in most cases, we're unable to get back to those that don't submit our Farfel's Rescue adoption application. Thanks very much for choosing rescue.

My name is Chowder!,You may recognize me from the SPCA of Northern Nevada's presidential pet race of 2020. I was the Vice Purrsidential nominee, so you could say I'm an important public figure. I'm also best known for my "wobble" insight on the world. I have Cerebellar Hypoplasia, a neurological condition that causes me to wobble when I walk. I can run, jump, and play just like any other cat. I just require a soft surface to land on. After a day of play, my friends here at the SPCA know how much I love cuddling, so sometimes they keep me in a special sling so I can assist with their work and give some valuable insight.
